name: Blast
author: Christiam Camacho, Thomas Madden, George Coulouris, Vahram Avagyan, Ning Ma, Tao Tao, Richa Agarwala
description: National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). These applications have been revamped to provide an improved user interface, new features, and performance improvements compared to its counterparts in the NCBI C Toolkit. Hereafter we shall distinguish the C Toolkit BLAST command line applications from these command line applications by referring to the latter as the BLAST+ applications, which have been developed using the NCBI C++ Toolkit (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=toolkit.TOC&depth=2).

commands.name: blastp
commands.description: Traditional BLASTP to compare a protein query to a protein database

arguments.name: -best_hit_overhang
arguments.description: Overhang value for Best-Hit algorithm. For more details, see the section Best-Hits filtering algorithm.

arguments.name: -out
arguments.description: Name of the file to write the application’s output. Defaults to stdout.

arguments.name: -best_hit_score_edge
arguments.description: Score edge value for Best-Hit algorithm. For more details, see the section Best-Hits filtering algorithm.

arguments.name: -db
arguments.description: File name of BLAST database to search the query against. Unless an absolute path is used, the database will be searched relative to the current working directory first, then relative to the value specified by the BLASTDB environment variable, then relative to the BLASTDB configuration value specified in the configuration file.

arguments.name: -dbsize
arguments.description: Effective length of the database.

arguments.name: -dbtype
arguments.description: Molecule type stored or to store in a BLAST database.

arguments.name: -db_soft_mask
arguments.description: Filtering algorithm ID to apply to the database as soft masking for subject sequences. The algorithm IDs for a given BLAST database can be obtained by invoking blastdbcmd with its -info flag (only shown if such filtering in the BLAST database is available). For more details see the section Masking in BLAST databases.

arguments.name: -culling_limit
arguments.description: Ensures that more than the specified number of HSPs are not aligned to the same part of the query. This option was designed for searches with a lot of repetitive matches, but if possible it is probably more efficient to mask the query to remove the repetitive sequences.

arguments.name: -entrez_query
arguments.description: Restrict the search of the BLAST database to the results of the Entrez query provided.

arguments.name: -evalue
arguments.description: Expectation value threshold for saving hits.

arguments.name: -export_search_strategy
arguments.description: Name of the file where to save the search strategy (see section titled BLAST search strategies) .

arguments.name: -gapextend
arguments.description: Cost to extend a gap.

arguments.name: -gapopen
arguments.description: Cost to open a gap.

arguments.name: -gilist
arguments.description: File containing a list of GIs to restrict the BLAST database to search. The expect values in the BLAST results are based upon the sequences actually searched and not on the underlying database.

arguments.name: -h
arguments.description: Displays the application’s brief documentation.

arguments.name: -help
arguments.description: Displays the application’s detailed documentation.

arguments.name: -html
arguments.description: Enables the generation of HTML output suitable for viewing in a web browser.

arguments.name: -import_search_strategy
arguments.description: Name of the file where to read the search strategy to execute (see section titled BLAST search strategies) .

arguments.name: -lcase_masking
arguments.description: Interpret lowercase letters in query sequence(s) as masked.

arguments.name: -matrix
arguments.description: Name of the scoring matrix to use.

arguments.name: -max_target_seqs
arguments.description: Maximum number of aligned sequences to keep from the BLAST database.

arguments.name: -negative_gilist
arguments.description: File containing a list of GIs to exclude from the BLAST database.

arguments.name: -num_alignments
arguments.description: Number of alignments to show in the BLAST output.

arguments.name: -num_descriptions
arguments.description: Number of one-line descriptions to show in the BLAST output.

arguments.name: -num_threads
arguments.description: Number of threads to use during the search.

arguments.name: -outfmt
arguments.description: Allows for the specification of the search application’s output format. A listing of the possible format types is available via the search applications -help option. If a custom output format is desired, this can be specified by providing a quoted string composed of the desired output format (tabular, tabular with comments, or comma-separated value), a space, and a space delimited list of output specifiers. The list of supported output specifiers is available via the -help command line option. Unsupported output specifiers will be ignored. This should be specified using double quotes if there are spaces in the output format specification.

arguments.name: -parse_deflines
arguments.description: Parse the query and subject deflines.

arguments.name: -query
arguments.description: Name of the file containing the query sequence(s), or ‘-‘ if these are provided on standard input.

arguments.name: -query_loc
arguments.description: Location of the first query sequence to search in 1-based offsets (Format: start-stop) .

arguments.name: -remote
arguments.description: Instructs the application to submit the search to NCBI for remote execution.

arguments.name: -searchsp
arguments.description: Effective length of the search space.

arguments.name: -seg
arguments.description: Arguments to SEG filtering algorithm (use ‘no’ to disable) .

arguments.name: -show_gis
arguments.description: Show NCBI GIs in deflines in the BLAST output.

arguments.name: -soft_masking
arguments.description: Apply filtering locations as soft masks (i.e.: only when finding alignment seeds) .

arguments.name: -subject
arguments.description: Name of the file containing the subject sequence(s) to search.

arguments.name: -subject_loc
arguments.description: Location of the first subject sequence to search in 1-based offsets (Format: start-stop) .

arguments.name: -strand
arguments.description: Strand(s) of the query sequence to search.

arguments.name: -threshold
arguments.description: Minimum word score such that the word is added to the BLAST lookup table.

arguments.name: -ungapped
arguments.description: Perform ungapped alignments only.

arguments.name: -version
arguments.description: Displays the application’s version.

arguments.name: -window_size
arguments.description: Size of the window for multiple hits algorithm, use 0 to specify 1-hit algorithm.

arguments.name: -word_size
arguments.description: Word size for word finder algorithm.

arguments.name: -xdrop_gap
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for preliminary gapped extensions.

arguments.name: -xdrop_gap_final
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for final gapped alignment.

arguments.name: -xdrop_ungap
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for ungapped extensions.

arguments.name: -task
arguments.description: Specify the task to execute. For more details, refer to the section on tasks.

arguments.name: -comp_based_stats
arguments.description: Select the appropriate composition based statistics mode (applicable only to blastp and tblastn). Available choices and references are available by invoking the application with -help option.

arguments.name: -use_sw_tback
arguments.description: Instead of using the X-dropoff gapped alignment algorithm, use SmithWaterman to compute locally optimal alignments.

outputs.name: -out
outputs.description: Name of the file to write the application’s output. Defaults to stdout.

arguments.description: Use non-greedy dynamic programming extension.

arguments.description: Minimum raw gapped score to keep an alignment in the preliminary gapped and traceback stages.

arguments.name: -template_type
arguments.description: Discontiguous megablast template type.

arguments.name: -template_length
arguments.description: Discontiguous megablast template length.

arguments.name: -off_diagonal_range
arguments.description: Maximum number of diagonals separating two hits used to initiate an extension. Increasing values of this parameter lead to a longer run time, but more sensitive results. If this parameter is set, a value of five is suggested. Only discontiguous megablast uses two hits by default.

commands.name: tblastx
commands.description: Which compares the six-frame translations of a nucleotide query sequence against the six-frame translations of a nucleotide sequence database. Due its high computation cost and background noise, tblastx should only be used as a last resort. Users with regular and large scale needs of tblastx should install command line BLAST and run the searches locally.

The list of supported output specifiers is available via the -help command line option. Unsupported output specifiers will be ignored. This should be specified using double quotes if there are spaces in the output format specification.

commands.name: blastdbcmd
commands.description: Retreive taxonomic data from the BLAST databases

arguments.name: -best_hit_overhang
arguments.description: Overhang value for Best-Hit algorithm. For more details, see the section Best-Hits filtering algorithm.

arguments.name: -out
arguments.description: Name of the file to write the application’s output. Defaults to stdout.

arguments.name: -best_hit_score_edge
arguments.description: Score edge value for Best-Hit algorithm. For more details, see the section Best-Hits filtering algorithm.

arguments.name: -db
arguments.description: File name of BLAST database to search the query against. Unless an absolute path is used, the database will be searched relative to the current working directory first, then relative to the value specified by the BLASTDB environment variable, then relative to the BLASTDB configuration value specified in the configuration file.

arguments.name: -dbsize
arguments.description: Effective length of the database.

arguments.name: -dbtype
arguments.description: Molecule type stored or to store in a BLAST database.

arguments.name: -db_soft_mask
arguments.description: Filtering algorithm ID to apply to the database as soft masking for subject sequences. The algorithm IDs for a given BLAST database can be obtained by invoking blastdbcmd with its -info flag (only shown if such filtering in the BLAST database is available). For more details see the section Masking in BLAST databases.

arguments.name: -culling_limit
arguments.description: Ensures that more than the specified number of HSPs are not aligned to the same part of the query. This option was designed for searches with a lot of repetitive matches, but if possible it is probably more efficient to mask the query to remove the repetitive sequences.

arguments.name: -entrez_query
arguments.description: Restrict the search of the BLAST database to the results of the Entrez query provided.

arguments.name: -evalue
arguments.description: Expectation value threshold for saving hits.

arguments.name: -export_search_strategy
arguments.description: Name of the file where to save the search strategy (see section titled BLAST search strategies) .

arguments.name: -gapextend
arguments.description: Cost to extend a gap.

arguments.name: -gapopen
arguments.description: Cost to open a gap.

arguments.name: -gilist
arguments.description: File containing a list of GIs to restrict the BLAST database to search. The expect values in the BLAST results are based upon the sequences actually searched and not on the underlying database.

arguments.name: -h
arguments.description: Displays the application’s brief documentation.

arguments.name: -help
arguments.description: Displays the application’s detailed documentation.

arguments.name: -html
arguments.description: Enables the generation of HTML output suitable for viewing in a web browser.

arguments.description: Name of the file where to read the search strategy to execute (see section titled BLAST search strategies) .

arguments.name: -lcase_masking
arguments.description: Interpret lowercase letters in query sequence(s) as masked.

arguments.description: Name of the scoring matrix to use.

arguments.description: Maximum number of aligned sequences to keep from the BLAST database.

arguments.name: -target_only
arguments.description: The definition line of the sequence should contain target GI only.

arguments.name: -get_dups

arguments.name: -line_length
arguments.description: Line length for output (applicable only with FASTA output format).

arguments.name: -ctrl_a
arguments.description: Use Ctrl-A as the non-redundant defline separator (applicable only with FASTA output format).

arguments.name: -mask_sequence_with
arguments.description: Allows the specification of a filtering algorithm ID from the BLAST database to apply to the sequence data. Applicable only with FASTA and sequence data output formats (%f and %s respectively).

arguments.name: -list
arguments.description: Display BLAST databases available in the directory provided as an argument to this option.

arguments.name: -list_outfmt
arguments.description: Allows for the specification of the output format for the -list option; a listing of the possible format types is available via the application’s -help option. Unsupported output specifiers will be ignored. This option’s argument should be specified using double quotes if there are spaces in the output format specification.

arguments.name: -recursive
arguments.description: Recursively traverse the directory provided to the –list option to find and display available BLAST databases.

arguments.name: -show_blastdb_search_path

arguments.description: Location of the first query sequence to search in 1-based offsets (Format: start-stop) .

arguments.name: -remote
arguments.description: Instructs the application to submit the search to NCBI for remote execution.

arguments.name: -searchsp
arguments.description: Effective length of the search space.

arguments.name: -seg
arguments.description: Arguments to SEG filtering algorithm (use ‘no’ to disable) .

arguments.name: -show_gis
arguments.description: Show NCBI GIs in deflines in the BLAST output.

arguments.name: -soft_masking
arguments.description: Apply filtering locations as soft masks (i.e.: only when finding alignment seeds) .

arguments.name: -subject
arguments.description: Name of the file containing the subject sequence(s) to search.

arguments.name: -subject_loc
arguments.description: Location of the first subject sequence to search in 1-based offsets (Format: start-stop) .

arguments.name: -strand
arguments.description: Strand(s) of the query sequence to search.

arguments.name: -threshold
arguments.description: Minimum word score such that the word is added to the BLAST lookup table.

arguments.name: -ungapped
arguments.description: Perform ungapped alignments only.

arguments.name: -version
arguments.description: Displays the application’s version.

arguments.name: -window_size
arguments.description: Size of the window for multiple hits algorithm, use 0 to specify 1-hit algorithm.

arguments.name: -word_size
arguments.description: Word size for word finder algorithm.

arguments.name: -xdrop_gap
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for preliminary gapped extensions.

arguments.name: -xdrop_gap_final
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for final gapped alignment.

arguments.name: -xdrop_ungap
arguments.description: X-dropoff value (in bits) for ungapped extensions.

arguments.name: -rid
arguments.description: BLAST RID of the report to be formatted.

arguments.name: -archive
arguments.description: File produced by BLAST application using –outfmt 11

outputs.name: -out
outputs.description: Name of the file to write the application’s output. Defaults to stdout.

inputs.name: -query
inputs.description: Name of the file containing the query sequence(s), or ‘-‘ if these are provided on standard input.

commands.name: blastall
commands.description: blastall is controlled by several parameters. Many of the parameters have default settings and don't need to be explicitly assigned.
